makers.displaydate: 1904–1988; born Los Angeles, CA; died New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Isamu Noguchi, 1904–1988; born Los Angeles, CA; died New York, NY

texts.textentryhtml: Noguchi created White Sun while developing The Garden (Pyramid, Sun, and Cube) at Yale University. Princeton's is one of several study versions; others include a black granite sun now in Seattle. Drawing on both Eastern and Western cultural traditions, Noguchi's sculptures appear to possess the quality of effortlessness, a virtue Japanese artists once valued above perfection.

bibliography.boilertext: Patrick Joseph Kelleher, Living with Modern Sculpture: the John B. Putnam, Jr., Memorial Collection, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 1982).
bibliography.citation: Patrick Joseph Kelleher, Living with Modern Sculpture: the John B. Putnam, Jr., Memorial Collection, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 1982)., 80–83

bibliography.citation: Karin Dienst, ed., Sculpture of Princeton University: including works from the John B. Putnam Jr. Memorial Collection, (Princeton, NJ: Published by the Office of Communications, in association with the Princeton University Art Museum, 2004)., 16–17, illus.

bibliography.citation: Jane McCarthy and Laurily K. Epstein, A guide to the sculpture parks and gardens of America, (New York, NY: Michael Kesend Pub., 1996).
